owl:Ontology.dc:description: This is the RDF Schema for the RDF vocabulary terms in the RDF Namespace, defined in RDF 1.1 Concepts.
owl:Ontology.dc:title: The OWL 2 Schema vocabulary (OWL 2)
The RDF Concepts Vocabulary (RDF)
The RDF Schema vocabulary (RDFS)
owl:Ontology.terms:contributor: Participants in W3C's Semantic Web Deployment Working Group.
owl:Ontology.terms:creator: Alistair Miles
Sean Bechhofer
owl:Ontology.terms:description: An RDF vocabulary for describing the basic structure and content of concept schemes such as thesauri, classification schemes, subject heading lists, taxonomies, 'folksonomies', other types of controlled vocabulary, and also concept schemes embedded in glossaries and terminologies.
owl:Ontology.terms:title: SKOS Vocabulary
owl:Ontology.rdfs:comment: This ontology partially describes the built-in classes and properties that together form the basis of the RDF/XML syntax of OWL 2. The content of this ontology is based on Tables 6.1 and 6.2 in Section 6.4 of the OWL 2 RDF-Based Semantics specification, available at http://www.w3.org/TR/owl2-rdf-based-semantics/. Please note that those tables do not include the different annotations (labels, comments and rdfs:isDefinedBy links) used in this file. Also note that the descriptions provided in this ontology do not provide a complete and correct formal description of either the syntax or the semantics of the introduced terms (please see the OWL 2 recommendations for the complete and normative specifications). Furthermore, the information provided by this ontology may be misleading if not used with care. This ontology SHOULD NOT be imported into OWL ontologies. Importing this file into an OWL 2 DL ontology will cause it to become an OWL 2 Full ontology and may have other, unexpected, consequences.

Description.rdfs:comment: A human-readable name for the subject.
Description.rdfs:label: label

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The annotation property that indicates that a given ontology is backward compatible with another ontology.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: backwardCompatibleWith

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The annotation property that indicates that a given entity has been deprecated.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: deprecated

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that is used for importing other ontologies into a given ontology.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: imports

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The annotation property that indicates that a given ontology is incompatible with another ontology.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: incompatibleWith

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The annotation property that indicates the predecessor ontology of a given ontology.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: priorVersion

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that identifies the version IRI of an ontology.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: versionIRI

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The annotation property that provides version information for an ontology or another OWL construct.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: versionInfo

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The range of skos:altLabel is the class of RDF plain literals.
skos:prefLabel, skos:altLabel and skos:hiddenLabel are pairwise disjoint properties.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: alternative label
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: An alternative lexical label for a resource.
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:example: Acronyms, abbreviations, spelling variants, and irregular plural/singular forms may be included among the alternative labels for a concept. Mis-spelled terms are normally included as hidden labels (see skos:hiddenLabel).

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: change note
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A note about a modification to a concept.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: definition
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: editorial note
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A note for an editor, translator or maintainer of the vocabulary.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: example
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: An example of the use of a concept.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The range of skos:hiddenLabel is the class of RDF plain literals.
skos:prefLabel, skos:altLabel and skos:hiddenLabel are pairwise disjoint properties.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: hidden label
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A lexical label for a resource that should be hidden when generating visual displays of the resource, but should still be accessible to free text search operations.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: history note
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: note
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A general note, for any purpose.
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:scopeNote: This property may be used directly, or as a super-property for more specific note types.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: A resource has no more than one value of skos:prefLabel per language tag, and no more than one value of skos:prefLabel without language tag.
The range of skos:prefLabel is the class of RDF plain literals.
skos:prefLabel, skos:altLabel and skos:hiddenLabel are pairwise disjoint properties.
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: preferred label
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language.

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: scope note
owl:AnnotationProperty.skos:definition: A note that helps to clarify the meaning and/or the use of a concept.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: flowSink
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Location where the flow is going

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: flowSource
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Location where flow is coming from

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: isPartialSubComponentOf
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: a part of the subject component is accounted for by the object component

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: isSubComponentOf
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: the entirety of the subject is accounted for within the object component

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: usedBy
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: The State (or Federal Agency) that uses this element in a formalized water budgeting calculation or process

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The first item in the subject RDF list.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: first

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The object of the subject RDF statement.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: object

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The predicate of the subject RDF statement.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: predicate

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The rest of the subject RDF list after the first item.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: rest

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The subject of the subject RDF statement.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: subject

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The subject is an instance of a class.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: type

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Idiomatic property used for structured values.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: value

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: A domain of the subject property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: domain

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: A member of the subject resource.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: member

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: A range of the subject property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: range

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The subject is a subclass of a class.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: subClassOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The subject is a subproperty of a property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: subPropertyOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the class that a universal property restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: allValuesFrom

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the predicate of an annotated axiom or annotated annotation.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: annotatedProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the subject of an annotated axiom or annotated annotation.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: annotatedSource

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the object of an annotated axiom or annotated annotation.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: annotatedTarget

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the predicate of a negative property assertion.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: assertionProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The object property that does not relate any two individuals.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: bottomObjectProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that a given class is the complement of another class.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: complementOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that a given data range is the complement of another data range with respect to the data domain.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: datatypeComplementOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given individuals are different.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: differentFrom

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that a given class is equivalent to the disjoint union of a collection of other classes.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: disjointUnionOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given classes are disjoint.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: disjointWith

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of pairwise different individuals in a owl:AllDifferent axiom.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: distinctMembers

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given classes are equivalent, and that is used to specify datatype definitions.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: equivalentClass

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given properties are equivalent.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: equivalentProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of properties that jointly build a key.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: hasKey

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the property that a self restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: hasSelf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the individual that a has-value restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: hasValue

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of classes or data ranges that build an intersection.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: intersectionOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given properties are inverse.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: inverseOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of members in either a owl:AllDifferent, owl:AllDisjointClasses or owl:AllDisjointProperties axiom.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: members

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the class that a qualified object cardinality restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: onClass

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the data range that a qualified data cardinality restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: onDataRange

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the datatype that a datatype restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: onDatatype

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the n-tuple of properties that a property restriction on an n-ary data range refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: onProperties

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the property that a property restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: onProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of individuals or data values that build an enumeration.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: oneOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the n-tuple of properties that build a sub property chain of a given property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: propertyChainAxiom

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given properties are disjoint.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: propertyDisjointWith

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines that two given individuals are equal.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: sameAs

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the class that an existential property restriction refers to.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: someValuesFrom

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the subject of a negative property assertion.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: sourceIndividual

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the object of a negative object property assertion.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: targetIndividual

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the value of a negative data property assertion.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: targetValue

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The object property that relates every two individuals.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: topObjectProperty

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of classes or data ranges that build a union.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: unionOf

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the collection of facet-value pairs that define a datatype restriction.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: withRestrictions
has broader match
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:broadMatch is used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two conceptual resources in different concept schemes.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Broader concepts are typically rendered as parents in a concept hierarchy (tree).
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has broader
broader
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: By convention, skos:broader is only used to assert an immediate (i.e. direct) hierarchical link between two conceptual resources.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has broader transitive
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:broaderTransitive is a transitive superproperty of skos:broader.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: By convention, skos:broaderTransitive is not used to make assertions. Rather, the properties can be used to draw inferences about the transitive closure of the hierarchical relation, which is useful e.g. when implementing a simple query expansion algorithm in a search application.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has close match
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:closeMatch is used to link two concepts that are sufficiently similar that they can be used interchangeably in some information retrieval applications. In order to avoid the possibility of "compound errors" when combining mappings across more than two concept schemes, skos:closeMatch is not declared to be a transitive property.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: skos:exactMatch is disjoint with each of the properties skos:broadMatch and skos:relatedMatch.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has exact match
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications. skos:exactMatch is a transitive property, and is a sub-property of skos:closeMatch.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has top concept
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates, by convention, a concept scheme to a concept which is topmost in the broader/narrower concept hierarchies for that scheme, providing an entry point to these hierarchies.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is in scheme
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: A concept may be a member of more than one concept scheme.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: These concept mapping relations mirror semantic relations, and the data model defined below is similar (with the exception of skos:exactMatch) to the data model defined for semantic relations. A distinct vocabulary is provided for concept mapping relations, to provide a convenient way to differentiate links within a concept scheme from links between concept schemes. However, this pattern of usage is not a formal requirement of the SKOS data model, and relies on informal definitions of best practice.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is in mapping relation with
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates two concepts coming, by convention, from different schemes, and that have comparable meanings

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has member
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a collection to one of its members.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: For any resource, every item in the list given as the value of the skos:memberList property is also a value of the skos:member property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has member list
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates an ordered collection to the RDF list containing its members.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has narrower match
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:narrowMatch is used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two conceptual resources in different concept schemes.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Narrower concepts are typically rendered as children in a concept hierarchy (tree).
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has narrower
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a concept to a concept that is more specific in meaning.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: By convention, skos:broader is only used to assert an immediate (i.e. direct) hierarchical link between two conceptual resources.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has narrower transitive
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:narrowerTransitive is a transitive superproperty of skos:narrower.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: By convention, skos:narrowerTransitive is not used to make assertions. Rather, the properties can be used to draw inferences about the transitive closure of the hierarchical relation, which is useful e.g. when implementing a simple query expansion algorithm in a search application.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: skos:related is disjoint with skos:broaderTransitive
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has related
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a concept to a concept with which there is an associative semantic relationship.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has related match
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: skos:relatedMatch is used to state an associative mapping link between two conceptual resources in different concept schemes.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is in semantic relation with
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Links a concept to a concept related by meaning.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:scopeNote: This property should not be used directly, but as a super-property for all properties denoting a relationship of meaning between concepts.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: is top concept in scheme
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relates a concept to the concept scheme that it is a top level concept of.

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The data property that does not relate any individual to any data value.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: bottomDataProperty

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of an exact cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: cardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of a maximum cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: maxCardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of a maximum qualified cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: maxQualifiedCardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of a minimum cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: minCardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of a minimum qualified cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: minQualifiedCardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The property that determines the cardinality of an exact qualified cardinality restriction.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: qualifiedCardinality

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The data property that relates every individual to every data value.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: topDataProperty
notation
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:definition: A notation, also known as classification code, is a string of characters such as "T58.5" or "303.4833" used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme.
owl:DatatypeProperty.skos:scopeNote: By convention, skos:notation is used with a typed literal in the object position of the triple.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of containers of alternatives.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Alt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of container membership properties, rdf:_1, rdf:_2, ..., all of which are sub-properties of 'member'.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ContainerMembershipProperty

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of collections of pairwise different individuals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AllDifferent

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of collections of pairwise disjoint classes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AllDisjointClasses

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of collections of pairwise disjoint properties.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AllDisjointProperties

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of annotated annotations for which the RDF serialization consists of an annotated subject, predicate and object.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Annotation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of annotated axioms for which the RDF serialization consists of an annotated subject, predicate and object.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Axiom

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of OWL data ranges, which are special kinds of datatypes. Note: The use of the IRI owl:DataRange has been deprecated as of OWL 2. The IRI rdfs:Datatype SHOULD be used instead.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DataRange

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The class of negative property assertions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: NegativePropertyAssertion
Collection
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: Labelled collections can be used where you would like a set of concepts to be displayed under a 'node label' in the hierarchy.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Concept
owl:Class.skos:definition: An idea or notion; a unit of thought.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Concept Scheme
owl:Class.skos:definition: A set of concepts, optionally including statements about semantic relationships between those concepts.
owl:Class.skos:example: Thesauri, classification schemes, subject heading lists, taxonomies, 'folksonomies', and other types of controlled vocabulary are all examples of concept schemes. Concept schemes are also embedded in glossaries and terminologies.
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: A concept scheme may be defined to include concepts from different sources.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Ordered Collection
owl:Class.skos:definition: An ordered collection of concepts, where both the grouping and the ordering are meaningful.
owl:Class.skos:scopeNote: Ordered collections can be used where you would like a set of concepts to be displayed in a specific order, and optionally under a 'node label'.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Agricultural and Municipal Depletions-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water from surface or groundwater supplied for municipal and agricultural uses provided through a municipal distribution system that is consumed by agriculture and municipal use and does not return to a natural water source or another body of water.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Agricultural and Municipal Diversions-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water from surface or groundwater supplied for municipal and agricultural uses provided through a municipal distribution system that remains in the budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Agricultural Consumptive Use-WY
Agricultural Depletions-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Portion of water withdrawn from a surface or groundwater source that is consumed by agriculture and does not return to a natural water source or another body of water.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Agricultural Potential Consumptive Use-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Portion of water withdrawn from a surface or groundwater source that is might be consumed by agriculture and might not return to a natural water source or another body of water. This could include consumptive use and return flow.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Applied Water-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water delivered to the intake of a city water system, a factory, a farm headgate, managed wetlands, or managed aquifer recharge; it includes all sources of supply (surface water, groundwater, applied water reuse, and recycled water).

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Area Outflows-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water leaving through rivers at the periphery of a water budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Average Monthly Reservoir Gage Height
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Compute the average gage height of the water surface level, or the average reservoir content for each month, from daily measurements reported by the agency responsible for managing the reservoir. Sources of data include the NMISC, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the USBR, the USGS, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), and irrigation districts.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Average Use Rate
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Baseflow estimation requires two steps in StateMod and one step in TSTool: 1) StateMod adjusts USGS stream gage flows using historical records of operations to get baseflow time series at gaged points, for the gage period of record; 2) TSTool fills remaining baseflow by regression; 3) StateMod distributes baseflow gains above and between gages to user-specified, ungaged inflow nodes. These three steps are described below.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Baseflow
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Base flow data is used by the baseflow module to estimate base flows at river nodes that do not have hisoric records using the following formula:

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Not sure if River inflow and Basin Inflow are exactly the same
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Basin Inflow-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering through rivers at the periphery of a water budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Basin Outflow-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water leaving through rivers at the periphery of a water budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Handbook for Water Budget Development With or Without Models. California Deparment of Water Resources. Draft April 2019
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CA
CO Agricultural Meteorology Network Station (COAGM)
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Managed by Colorado Climate Center at Colorado State University. Available through HydroBase or from CoAgMet website.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Consumptive Use Method

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Diversion Records
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Division Engineer for each major river basin, along with Water Commissioners and other staff, is responsible for administering the water rights and taking measurements of streamflow and diversions in their basin. The responsibility of recording diversions extends to both surface and ground water use, however there is very little ground water used for irrigation in the Western Slope river basins, therefore this discussion will focus on surface water diversions. The daily diversion records are stored in HydroBase, and can be accessed either through the CDSS website or through data management interfaces.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Division of Water Resources Gages

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Irrigated Acreage Assessment
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Irrigated acreage assessments define the amount of acreage that was actively irrigated and cultivated in any given year. Irrigated acreage assessments can range in the level of attribution;
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: updated every 5 years; available on the state website

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Livestock Method
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: CO Municipal and Industrial Method
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Ground Water Storage-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Calculation of inflows minus outflows to the groundwater system

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Groundwater Storage-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Calculation of inflows minus outflows to the groundwater system

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Groundwater Storage-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Net change in the volume of groundwater stored within the underlying aquifer of the water budget zone.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Land System Storage-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Net change in the volume of water stored within the land system, which includes ponded water on the land surface (not including streams, lakes, and conveyance facilities) and soil moisture within the unsaturated zone, which includes the root zone.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Surface Water Storage-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Net change in the volume of water stored within the surface water system, which includes lakes and reservoirs, streams, and conveyance facilities.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Change in Surface Water Storage-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Change in the amount of water stored as groundwater

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Class A Pan Evaporation Data
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Obtain Class A pan evaporation data recorded for each month from the weather station that best represents climate conditions in the study area. Measurements of monthly and annual evaporation from U.S. Weather Bureau Class A pans are generally available from NOAA.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Colorado Census Bureau
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Colorado StateMod
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: State of Colorado's Stream Simulation Model (StateMod) is a water allocation and accounting model capable of making comparative analyses of various historical and future water management policies in a river basin. It is designed to be applied to any river basin through appropriate input data preparation.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Commercial-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Commercial category includes: Self-supplied businesses (e.g., motels, restaurants, recreational resorts, and campgrounds), Public and private institutions (e.g., public and private schools and hospitals) involved in the trade of goods or provision of services, Self-supplied golf courses that are not supplied by entities covered in the Public Water Supply category, Greenhouses and nurseries that both produce and sell products to the general public on the same premises, Off-stream fish hatcheries that produce fish for release, and Non-metered schools.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Consumptive Ratio
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Conveyance Evaporation-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water evaporated into the atmosphere from conveyance facilities, other than streams, during water delivery.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Conveyance Losses for Allocated Diversions-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water diverted primarily to operate regulated rivers and utility supply networks to enable the delivery of water for which an allocation has been recognised.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Conveyance Seepage-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water recharged to the groundwater system from the conveyance facilities, other than streams, during water delivery.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Cropland Precipitation-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth specifically on cropland area, as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Crop Consumptive Use-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Amount of water that does not return to its source after it has been diverted and put to beneficial use by agriculture.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Crop Irrigation Requirement
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Crop irrigation requirement is calculated as PCU less effective precipitation. The amount of water crops could consume from a full irrigation supply.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Crop Irrigation Requirement Estimation Method
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Crop irrigation requirement is calculated as PCU less effective precipitation.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Daily ASCE Standardized Penman-Monteith
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: In 1999, the Irrigation Association requested a technical committee of the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) that is involved with evapotranspiration to propose one standardized equation and set of procedures for calculating evapotranspiration. The result of this process was that two equations (one for a short crop named ETo and one for a taller crop named ETr) were developed. These equations were based on framework suggested in a FAO56 (Allen, 1998) document that assumed a constant for the psychometric constant, simplified the air density term and simplified the vapor aerodynamic resistance term. For each type of reference crop (short or tall), constants were assigned in the ASCE Standardized Penman-Monteith equation for the vegetation height, latent heat of vaporization, and surface resistance.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Daily effective precipitation (i.e. effective rainfall, Re) may be estimated in StateCU using three methods that can be selected by the user. Daily effective precipitation methods can only be used with daily consumptive use analyses.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Daily Effective Precipitation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The portion of precipitation falling during the cropgrowing season that is available to meet the evapotranspiration requirements of the crop.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Daily Modified Hargreaves
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition:
StateCU uses a Modified Hargreaves radiation method to estimate ET that was developed by Agro Engineering, Inc. This method was specifically developed for the San Luis Valley and should be used with caution in other areas. The original Hargreaves method used temperature and radiation data to estimate ET for an Alta fescue grass crop. The Modified Hargreaves approach includes a wind function to recognize the advective transfer of water away from plant stomatal openings under windy conditions as follows:
ETo=(FRsTavg)/1498.6

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Project underway to use a modified analysis for the Upper Basin - USBR
Used in CO where data are available, including areas of the Colorado River Basin
Used in NM where data are available, not used in San Juan River Basin
Used in UT where data available, not used in Colorado River Basin
Used in WY where data is available, including areas of the Green River Basin since 2011
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Daily Penman-Monteith
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Penman-Monteith method for determining daily reference crop ET uses minimum and maximum temperature, vapor pressure, solar radiation and wind run data. Reference crop ET for alfalfa is the rate at which water, if available, is removed by the processes of evaporation and transpiration from soil and plant surfaces expressed as the depth of water used by a standard reference crop per unit time.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Direct Flow Demand - Monthly
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The monthly direct flow demand file contains demands for direct diversions for each month of the simulation period. Monthly data is required when the diversion station variable idvcom is set to 1 (monthly total demand) or 3 (monthly irrigation water requirement).

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Divertible Flow
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Portion of inflow that can be diverted in the budget zone under compact allocation

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Domestic Total Use-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Domestic water use is water used for personal, commercial, and other purposes that is not supplied by a municipality. Examples of domestic water use are rural singlefamily residences and highway rest-stops.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Effective Precipitation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Effective precipitation is the amount of precipitation during the irrigation season that is effective in satisfying a portion of PCU. The amount of water crops consume from precipitation.
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: At this time, each of the states (with the exception of Utah) and Reclamation rely on the SCS monthly method outlined in Technical Release 21 in the Colorado River Basin. Utah estimates effective precipitation to be 80 percent of total precipitation during the irrigation season.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Effective Precipitation Factor
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: F - a user-specified factor with the value ranging from 0 to 1

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Empirical Data for Small Reservoirs
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: In some areas there are small reservoirs that are not monitored on a regular basis. Many of these are not equipped with a gage to measure the water level, and area capacity curves are frequently not available. The NMOSE Dam Safety Bureau provided the most up-to-date area capacity data where possible for use in estimating evaporation. Because these reservoirs are small, and hydrological and meteorological data are typically unavailable, spending extensive time and effort to estimate annual evaporation is not recommended.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Evaporation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Parameter used in CO StateMod

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Evaporation-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Movement of water from the region's surface water to the atmosphere (water vapour)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Evaporation-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water evaporated from the land surface into the atmosphere

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Evaporation from Reservoirs-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Power category includes all self-supplied power generating facilities and water used in conjunction with coal-mining operations that are directly associated with a power generating facility that owns and/or operates the coal mines. Section 5.6 describes some power generating facilities and their associated water use.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Evapotranspiration-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering the atmosphere through the combined process of evaporation from soil and plant surfaces and transpiration from plants.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Exports-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water exported from the water budget zone as surface or groundwater

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Flood Return-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Return of flood waters from the flood plains. It excludes flood waters returning from seasonally connected wetlands and other surface water bodies.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gaged Surface Water Inflow-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering through surface waters at the periphery of a water budget zone that is measured by gages.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gaged Surface Water Outflow-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water exiting through surface waters at the periphery of a water budget zone that is measured by gages.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gross Actively Irrigated Acreage
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Irrigated acreage for the Report was compiled using the USDA Cropland Data Layer (CDL). The CDL is a georeferenced crop-specific land cover classification product with a 30 meter resolution that is produced annually. GIS was used to integrate the CDL crop types with a layer of potentially irrigated polygons covering the entire state. WUCB staff analyzed the results using aerial imagery to ensure accuracy. During this process, edits were made as needed to reflect on-the-ground conditions. For example, areas in the eastern part of the state that appeared to be dryland farmed were removed from the analysis. Ancillary data from the USBR, USDA Farm Service Agency, National Agricultural Statistics Service, NMISC, NMOSE district offices, irrigation districts, conservancy districts, and county extension agents were used to help validate and refine the totals obtained from the CDL and subsequent analysis.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gross Monthly Free Water Surface Evaporation
Gross Usage
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Ground Water Inflow-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering as groundwater from a water budget zone through its subsurface boundaries.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Ground Water Outflow-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water leaving as groundwater from a water budget zone through its subsurface boundaries.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Discharge-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater discharge to the region's surface water.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Diversions-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water diverted from groundwater to human storage and distribution systems

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater ET-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater ET is calculated based on a calculated riparian ET rate multiplied by a remote sensing based estimate of riparian area.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Export-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of groundwater pumped (extracted) from the underlying aquifer for use outside the water budget zone. It does not include groundwater extraction, stored water extraction, and stored water export.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Extraction-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of groundwater pumped (extracted) from the underlying aquifer(s) for use within the water budget zone. It does not include groundwater export, stored water extraction, and stored water export.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Lateral flow of groundwater into the region's groundwater from inland groundwater aquifers that extend outside the region. It excludes lateral flow of groundwater from coastal aquifers
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Inflows-AUS
Groundwater Inflows-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: As used in the NMDSWB, groundwater inflows into a given MBAU flow in from outside of the MBAU. FOr the purposes of the NBMDSWB, we assume that basin scale groundwater divides are the same as surface water divides

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Outflows-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Lateral flow of groundwater out of the region's groundwater to inland groundwater aquifers that extend outside the region. It excludes lateral flow of groundwater to coastal aquifers.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Outflows-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater flow across a political or watershed boundary cannot be directly measured, and must be calculated based on observed groundwater elevations and inferred geologic information, or extracted from regional groundwater models based on the same. In the 2015 version of the NMDSWB, groundwater outflows are largely unknown. The user has the option of setting groundwater outflows to a user selected constant value (with a default of zero), allowing a change in groundwater storage over the selected period to be calculated. However, this change would be averaged over the entire region being modeled (i.e. watershed, WPR, or county). This change in storage cannot be related to a change in groundwater elevation without detailed knowledge of aquifer characteristics, pumping and recharge, and developing a mechanistic groundwater model of the basin.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Return-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water returned to groundwater from human storage and distribution systems

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Stock-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The groundwatersystem conceptually representsall sub-surface water that is below the water table (saturated soil and rock).Total groundwater storage for the state of New Mexico is largely unknown. However, for select aquifers throughout the state, estimates of total groundwater storage do exist. Where these estimates are known they areused as input into the NMDSWB. Future work by other 17members of the New Mexico Water Resources Research Institute led Statewide Water Assessment includes plans to quantify total groundwater storage on a statewide basis.The NMDSWBdoes track groundwater storage changes over time. When groundwater storage estimates are not available the default initial storage is set to zero.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Groundwater Use-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of groundwater extracted from the underlying aquifer(s) for use within the water budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: High Plains Climate Center - University of Nebraska
Human Consumption-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: In the default setting of the NMDSWB human consumption is calculated for public and domestic water supplies (section 4.4.3), Irrigated agriculture (section 5.1), and livestock (4.4.4). Commercial, Industrial, Mining, and Power uses of water are provided by the OSE water use by categories report for counties and river basins

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Human Returns-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: In the NMDSWB return flows are calculated as the difference between withdrawals and consumption (depletions). The surface water return flux from human storage also includes releases from reservoir storage.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Human Storage and Distribution System Stock-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The human storage and distribution system (HSDS)stockrepresents water at any given time residing in manmade storage impoundments or distribution systems, such as public water supplies, irrigation canals, and reservoirs.Currently, only reservoir storage is tracked.For purposes of this mass balance, when water is added to storage in a reservoir, it is considered a diversion of available surface water to the HSDS, and when it is released from storage, it is considered a return to the available surface water system.Reservoirvolumes in the NMDSWBare calculated as the previous storage pluschange in storage which iscalculated as the difference between knownor calculatedinflows (gaged inflow, precipitation) and known or calculated outflows (gaged outflows, evaporation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:prefLabel: Human Storage and Distribution System Stock

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: HydroBase
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The State of Colorado's relational database used in the CDSS efforts. HydroBase contains historic, real‐time, and administrative water resources data.
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: StateDMI is often used to extract data from HydroBase and put it into CU models

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Imported Water-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water brought from outside the water budget zone for use within the water budget zone, such as State Water Project water, Central Valley Project water, water produced from desalination of ocean water, and water produced from desalination of deep groundwater from below the base of freshwater.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Imports-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water brought from outside the water budget zone for use within the water budget zone.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Industrial-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Industrial category includes self-supplied enterprises that process raw materials or manufacture durable or nondurable goods. This category also includes water used for the construction of highways, subdivisions, and other construction projects. 100% of industrial withdrawals are metered.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Industrial Consumptive Use-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Industrial water use is indexed to a variety of data sources depending on the industries present in a given river planning basin (Table 1). Common industrial uses include electrical generation, oil and gas production, and mining.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Industrial Total Use-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Industrial water use is indexed to a variety of data sources depending on the industries present in a given river planning basin (Table 1). Common industrial uses include electrical generation, oil and gas production, and mining.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Inter-region Coastal Inflow-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater transferred into the region through salt water intrusion

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Inter-region Coastal Outflow-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater discharged into coastal waters

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Interpolation from Other Records
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: When metered records for the water-use inventory year are incomplete, water use is estimated based on earlier records (as with other categories in this Report) or prorated based on similar operations.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Irrigated Agriculture-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Irrigated Agriculture category includes all withdrawals of water for the irrigation of crops grown on farms, ranches, and wildlife refuges.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Irrigated Agriculture Depletions-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Consumptive Use

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Irrigation Method
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Flood or sprinkler irrigation practices

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Irrigation Scheme Inflows-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Inflows into the region's irrigation scheme or increase of claims to water that may result in inflows into the region's irrigation scheme.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Irrigation Scheme Outflows-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Outflows from the region's irrigation scheme or decrease of claims to water that may result in outflows from the region's irrigation scheme.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Lake Evaporation-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of evaporation from lakes and reservoirs.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Lake Gain from Groundwater-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering lakes and reservoirs from the groundwater system.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Lake Loss to Groundwater-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water entering the groundwater system from lakes and reservoirs.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Land Surface Evapotranspiration-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Land surface evaporation is calculated by setting evaporation equal to precipitation less surface water runoff and recharge. In other words, of the rain that falls in an area in a given period of time, we assume that what doesn’t runoff or recharge evaporates to the atmosphere.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Land Surface Stock-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: For the purposes of the NMDSWB, the landsurface system conceptually representsmoisture stored in non-saturated soilsor geologic formations(the vadose zone),in vegetation, orany other surface water source that cannot be practicably diverted for human use.The water stored in this stock is difficult to measure at large scale and changes rapidly, and isnot calculated in this effort.Change in storage of this stock isset to zeroin the NMDSWBfor all timesteps.Thus, the land surface stock for purposes of this conceptual mass balance is a construct which allows precipitation to be partitioned into recharge, evaporation, and runoffat each timestep.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Livestock-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Livestock category includes water used to raise livestock, maintain self-supplied livestock facilities, and provide for on-farm processing of poultry and dairy products.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Livestock Consumptive Use-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Amount of water that does not return to its source after it has been diverted and put to beneficial use by livestock.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Livestock Count
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: METRIC
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Mapping evapotranspiration at high resolution with internalized calibration, publically available system developed through the University of Idaho. Mapping Evapotranspiration at high Resolution with Internalized Calibration (METRIC) is a model that utilizes satellite imagery and the energy balance method to spatially estimate actual ET. LandSat satellite imagery records thermal infrared light that is used in the energy balance to determine net radiation and the model utilizes local climate data to determine the remaining factors in the energy balance equation and calibrate the ET results. METRIC was recently used in the South Platte River basin in comparison to StateCU results for varying crop and irrigation practices.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Managed Aquifer Recharge-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The volume of water intentionally transferred to ground water assets (e.g. via injection wells) from other water assets: either surface water, urban water system or irrigation scheme.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Managed Aquifer Recharge-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water intentionally added to the groundwater system as part of defined recharge and water banking programs through spreading basins, injection wells, and other means.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Mining-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Mining category includes the following self-supplied enterprises that extract minerals occurring naturally in the earth’s crust: Solids, such as potash, coal, and smelting ores, Liquids, such as crude petroleum, Gases, such as natural gas. This category includes water used for oil and gas production (well drilling and secondary recovery of oil), quarrying, milling (crushing, screening, washing, flotation, etc.), and other processing done at the mine site or as part of a mining activity, as well as water removed from underground excavations (mine dewatering) and stored in—and evaporated from—tailings ponds. The Mining category also includes water used to irrigate new vegetative covers at former mine sites that have been reclaimed. It does not include the processing of raw materials, such as smelting ores, unless this activity occurs as an integral part of a mining operation and is included in an NMOSE permit.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Most common statewide in CO, NM, WY, UT

StateCU allows either the SCS TR-21 modified Blaney-Criddle or the original Blaney-Criddle procedure to estimate monthly evapotranspiration (ET). The empirical equation relates ET with mean air temperature and mean percentage daytime hours. The SCS TR-21 method was modified from the original Blaney-Criddle method to reasonably estimate short-period consumptive use. The modifications include the use of (1) climatic coefficients that are directly related to the mean air temperature for each of the consecutive short periods which constitutes the growing season and (2) coefficients which reflect the influence of the crop growth rates on consumptive use rates (SCS TR-21).
The basic relationship assumes that ET varies directly with the products of mean monthly air temperature and monthly percentage of annual daylight hours for an actively growing crop with adequate soil moisture. This is expressed mathematically as: u=kf
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Modified Blaney-Criddle
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The procedure used to calculate the final monthly consumptive use coefficient (k) distinguishes the MBC method from the OBC method, which uses a seasonal consumptive use coefficient.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Modified Blaney-Criddle with ET Elevation Adjustment
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The ASCE Manuals and Reports on Engineering Practice No. 70, Evapotranspiration and Irrigation Water Requirements (1990), recommends elevation adjustments for both the SCS and the FAO-24 Blaney-Criddle methods of 10% adjustment upward for each 1,000 meters increase in elevation above sea level. The adjustment corrects for lower mean temperatures that occur at higher elevations at a given level of solar radiation (i.e. mean temperatures do not reflect crops’ reactions to warm daytime temperatures and cool nights). The adjustment is applied to the potential consumptive use estimate and can be applied to any crop type. Note, however, that if locally calibrated crop coefficients are used in lieu of standard SCS or FAO-24 crop coefficients, the mean temperature correction is represented, and an additional elevation adjustment should not be applied.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Monthly Coalbed Methane Gas Production and Produced Water

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Effective precipitation (i.e. effective rainfall, Re) is the component of precipitation that is available to meet consumptive use. It does not include precipitation lost through runoff and deep percolation below the root zone. StateCU estimates the monthly effective precipitation using one of two methods.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Monthly Effective Precipitation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The portion of precipitation falling during the cropgrowing season that is available to meet the evapotranspiration requirements of the crop.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Monthly Evaporation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The net evaporation rate for each month, expressed as a depth of water in feet, is calculated by subtracting the measured rainfall, in feet, from the gross evaporation rate.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Monthly Gross Evaporation Rate
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The gross evaporation rate for each month is computed by multiplying the pan evaporation, which is expressed as a depth of water in feet, by the pan coefficient. In winter, if the evaporation pan is iced over, but the water surface of a nearby reservoir remains unfrozen, agencies such as the USBR have developed empirical equations based on temperature that can be used to estimate gross evaporation.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal and Industrial Consumptive Use-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Amount of water that does not return to its source after it has been diverted and put to beneficial use by municipal and industrial use.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal and Industrial Depeltion-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water Supplied for municipal and industrial uses, other than agriculture, provided through a municipal distribution system that is consumed and does not return to a natural water source or another body of water.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal and Industrial Diversions-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Water Supplied for municipal and industrial uses, other than agriculture, provided through a municipal distribution system that remains in the budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal and Industrial Return Flow-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Average flow for municipals areas

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal Consumptive Use-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Municipal water use is water supplied by a municipality for personal, commercial, and other purposes. Municipal water use is principally driven by the number of people living and working in a community.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: WY-Agricultural, Municipal, Domestic, and Industrial Water Use Index PDF
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Municipal Total Use-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Municipal water use is water supplied by a municipality for personal, commercial, and other purposes. Municipal water use is principally driven by the number of people living and working in a community.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: NDVIstar
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The NDVI StateCU methodology utilizes the normalized difference vegetative index (NDVI) measure of greenness within satellite images to apply a scaled measure of supply limitation to monthly actual ET estimates derived by the StateCU model when well diversions are an unknown. Linear scaling follows the NDVIstar approach proposed by D.P. Groeneveld and W.M. Baugh that can be overridden by measures of standing water. It is currently being developed by the State of Colorado to estimate water Actual ET and improve historic pumping estimates for the Rio Grande Basin over extended historical time periods, and has also been tested in the South Platte basin.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: NM Diversion Records
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Records available real-time for most diversions for 2011 through the current date. Diversions to Navajo Indian Irrigation Project measured.
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Diversions for most ditches in the San Juan River basin are routinely measured. Diversions to the NIIP are continuously recorded. The measured data is publically available from 2011 to the current date at http://meas.ose.state.nm.us/.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: NM Irrigated Acreage Assessment
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Irrigated acreage assessments define the amount of acreage that was actively irrigated and cultivated in any given year. Irrigated acreage assessments can range in the level of attribution;

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: NM Irrigation Withdrawals
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Where measured withdrawals are not available, the groundwater and surface water components must be estimated. Estimates are made by (1) examining historical water right diversion records, (2) comparing recorded stream flows with the estimated demand, (3) contacting personnel in the County Extension Service, Natural Resources Conservation Service, or individual farmers with local familiarity, or (4) using component estimates from the previous Water Use by Categories report.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: NMOSE Technical Report No. 48
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The most recent NMOSE indoor GPCD estimations are provided in NMOSE’s Technical Report No. 48 (Wilson, 1996). Technical Report No. 48 includes conservation measures available during the early 1990s, and estimates an indoor GPCD of 58.9. It is well established that there have been significant advances in the efficiency of indoor plumbing fixtures since both the Brown and Caldwell study and Technical Report No. 48 were published. The values provided from Technical Report No. 48 are intended for planning or benchmarking purposes.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Stations

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: National Weather Service Stations
Native Vegetation Consumptive Use-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Amount of water that does not return to its source after it has been diverted and put to beneficial use by natural vegetation.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Natural Flow Gain Distribution
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Estimation method used for ungaged surface water inflow

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Natural System Use-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water lost through evapotranspiration from normal plants and surface waters. Non human consumptive use.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: New Mexico Climate Center Stations
Non-allocated Extraction-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Extraction from the region's groundwater where no prior claim has been recognised

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy:
StateCU allows either the SCS TR-21 modified Blaney-Criddle or the original Blaney-Criddle procedure to estimate monthly evapotranspiration (ET). he SCS TR-21 method was modified from the original Blaney-Criddle method to reasonably estimate short-period consumptive use. The modifications include the use of (1) climatic coefficients that are directly related to the mean air temperature for each of the consecutive short periods which constitutes the growing season and (2) coefficients which reflect the influence of the crop growth rates on consumptive use rates (SCS TR-21).
The basic relationship assumes that ET varies directly with the products of mean monthly air temperature and monthly percentage of annual daylight hours for an actively growing crop with adequate soil moisture. This is expressed mathematically as: u=kf
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Original Blaney-Criddle
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Blaney Criddle relates ET with mean air temperature and mean percentage daytime hours. Formula: ETo = p (0.46 T mean +8)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Original Blaney-Criddle with ET Elevation Adjustment
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The ASCE Manuals and Reports on Engineering Practice No. 70, Evapotranspiration and Irrigation Water Requirements (1990), recommends elevation adjustments for both the SCS and the FAO-24 Blaney-Criddle methods of 10% adjustment upward for each 1,000 meters increase in elevation above sea level. The adjustment corrects for lower mean temperatures that occur at higher elevations at a given level of solar radiation (i.e. mean temperatures do not reflect crops’ reactions to warm daytime temperatures and cool nights). The adjustment is applied to the potential consumptive use estimate and can be applied to any crop type. Note, however, that if locally calibrated crop coefficients are used in lieu of standard SCS or FAO-24 crop coefficients, the mean temperature correction is represented, and an additional elevation adjustment should not be applied.

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Original Hargreaves
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The original Hargreaves method (1975) is a daily grass-reference radiation method that uses mean air temperature, the differential between daily maximum and minimum air temperatures, and solar radiation to estimate ET.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Other Increases-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Groundwater Inflows not accounted in other components

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Outflow-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of physical outflows from surface water during the reporting period to outside the region or to other stores

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Pan Approach
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The National Weather Service Class A Pan is 4 feet in diameter and 10 inches deep, It is made of unpainted, 22-gage galvanized iron and sits on a wooden pallet so that the bottom of the pan is raised 6 inches above the ground, allowing air to circulate. Site requirements specify that the pan be located on level ground, unobstructed by trees or buildings, so maximum exposure to sunlight is possible. The pan is filled with water to within 2 inches of the top and is refilled as soon as the water level drops 1 inch. The depth of water is measured with a micrometer hook gage located in a stilling well that supports the gage. An anemometer, which is used to measure wind movement, is mounted on the pallet, with the cups positioned 24 inches above the base of the pan. Maximum/minimum thermometers (which are stored in an instrument shelter) and a rain gage are also installed at the site. A 5-foot-high wire mesh fence encloses the entire installation. A pan reading is taken every morning.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Personal Outreach
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: When possible, these entities are identified through directories maintained by various business associations and/or regulatory agencies. The executive director or operator is then contacted by phone or mail to obtain an estimate of water use.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Population
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: Source: CU and Losses Report 2001-2005 (Word Doc)

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Population Served by Public Water Supply
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: In noncensus years, the population must be estimated. Methodologies may range from a simple linear extrapolation to complex correlations based on the demographic characteristics of individual communities. An important step in determining the utility’s population served is to separate the population of self-supplied residents from the total population of the larger community served by the PWS. Populations for communities not identified in the census are obtained from the water system manager, city clerk, regulatory agency, or estimated by some other means. Many water utilities estimate, with reasonable accuracy, the population they serve based on the total number of connections and the average number of residents per connection.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Potential Consumptive Use
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The amount of water crops could consume if provided a full supply, also called potential evapotranspiration (potential ET).

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Power-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Power category includes all self-supplied power generating facilities and water used in conjunction with coal-mining operations that are directly associated with a power generating facility that owns and/or operates the coal mines. Section 5.6 describes some power generating facilities and their associated water use.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Parameter for StateMod

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-AUS
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: All forms in which water falls on the region's surface water as rain, sleet, snow, hail, or drizzle

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth (land and surface water systems) as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost. -- Excepting Lakes

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-CO
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth (land and surface water systems) as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth (land and surface water systems) as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:isDefinedBy: PRISM Gridded Weather Data: The PRISM Climate Group’s 30m grid-cell resolution PRISM data for temperature and precipitation are used to estimate precipitation inputs across the state and for the Colorado and Bear River Basins.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation-WY
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Precipitation on Lakes-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of water vapor that falls to the earth (land and surface water systems) as rain, snow, hail, or is formed on the earth as dew, and frost.--Lakes Only

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Proration Factors
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Representing fraction of reach gain estimated to be tributary to a natural flow point

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Public Water Supply-NMOSE
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: The Public Water Supply category includes community water systems that rely on both surface water and groundwater diversions, and that consist of common collection, treatment, storage, and distribution facilities operated for the delivery of water to multiple service connections. For the purposes of this Report, these systems will be known as Public Water Suppliers (PWS) and this definition will include mutual domestic systems, mutual domestic water user associations, etc. Following are examples of multiple service connection systems: Municipalities that serve residential, commercial, and industrial water users, Prisons, Residential and mixed-use subdivisions, Mobile home parks. The Public Water Supply category also captures other water uses supplied by PWSs such as irrigation of golf courses, parks, athletic fields, or ponds/lakes. Wells permitted by the NMOSE under 72-12.1 New Mexico Statues Annotated (NMSA) 1978 are not included in this section.
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:note: 97% of Public Water Supply is metered

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Pumped Groundwater-UT
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of groundwater pumped (extracted) from the underlying aquifer(s) for use within the water budget zone

owl:NamedIndividual.dc:source: Assessing Agricultural Consumptive Use in the Upper Colorado River Basin
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: RESET
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Remote sensing of evapotranspiration, publically available system developed at Colorado State University. Remote Sensing of Evapotranspiration (RESET) is a remote sensing algorithm similar to the Surface Energy Balance Algorithm for Land (SEBAL) which is a satellite image-processing methodology used for computing actual ET for an entire satellite image. RESET, however, accounts for spatial and temporal variability by allowing more input from climate stations. RESET was developed by the IDS Group at Colorado State University. It is currently being used by Reclamation to investigate ET in the Uncompahgre River basin, and has been applied to areas of the Arkansas River Basin.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Rainfall
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Obtain the total rainfall recorded for each month. These data are published monthly for most weather stations operated by the NOAA. When a reservoir is completely covered with ice for part of a month, recorded precipitation should include only those days when the water surface was exposed.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Recharge-NM
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Recharge in the NMDSWB is calculated by assuming that without human diversions and returns, the groundwater system would be in steady state. Under this assumption, non-anthropogenic inflows (groundwater inflows from another MBAU and recharge) are equal to non-human related outflows (groundwater outflows to another MBAU, ET, and baseflow). Baseflow is water moving to the surface water system from the groundwater system, and is calculated as the portion of the total gains to the surface water system not attributed to runoff as described above. For each MBAU at each timestep, recharge is set equal to a moving 10 year average of the sum of the baseflow terms (calculated above as headwaters baseflow and baseflow of net gains between gages) plus groundwater ET and groundwater out minus groundwater in. Without averaging this term of a long time period it would ignore a basic characteristic of temporal lags in groundwater systems. Additionally, human impacts that change mass balance groundwater fluxes are at play across the state. Thus, both the assumption that recharge is equal to baseflow plus groundwater ET, and the assumption that non-human related groundwater fluxes are in balance are both open to legitimate criticism. These assumptions have provided the NMDSWB with a self-consistent way to estimate recharge which results in state level mass balance terms (especially groundwater storage change) that are reasonable, but as will be seen, produces some basin scale results that do not seem reasonable. The assumptions are in theory worse in regions of higher levels of groundwater pumping.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Recharge of Applied Water-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of applied water that travels vertically through the soil/unsaturated zones and reaches the saturated zone of the aquifer (groundwater system).

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Recharge of Precipitation-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of precipitation that travels vertically through the soil/unsaturated zones and reaches the saturated zone of the aquifer (groundwater system).

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Recycled Water Export-CA
owl:NamedIndividual.skos:definition: Volume of recycled water diverted from the land system within a water budget zone for use outside the zone. Recycled Water: Volume of water which, as a result of treatment of waste, is suitable for a direct beneficial use or a controlled use that would not otherwise occur within the water budget zone. It includes wastewater that is treated, stored, distributed, and reused or recirculated for beneficial uses.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Reservoir Evaporation-CO
